sect1.title: Getting Started With Veil2
sect1.para: This section aims to get you started.

sect4.title: RDBMS
sect4.para: Any currently-supported version of Postgres will be adequate.

sect4.title: Postgres Extensions
sect4.para:
You will need to be able to install the
pgbitmap; and pgcrypto.
extensions in your database. For pgbitmap, this means that you will probably need a full build environment unless you can find someone you trust who has a pre-built library you can use. See the pgbitmap web page for build instructions.

sect4.title: Operating System Environment
sect4.para: You should be able to install Veil2 on any operating system, though something Unix-like is recommended, as we use make for a lot of tasks. If you don't have make available, you can still install Veil2 but you will be doing it directly from the SQL scripts.

sect4.title: Software Required
sect4.para: For installation from tarballs, you will only need a command to unpack the tar file.

sect3.para: You may install either from pre-built tarballs, or directly from the git repository. Unless you have some need to use the git repository, use the tarball (TODO: refs).

sect4.para:
Download the file into a fresh directory, and unpack its contents:

sect4.title: Building The HTML Documentation
sect4.para:
You probably don't need to do this, but if you want to.
$ cd <to the veil2 directory> $ ./configure $ make html
The documentation will be created in the html directory. Open the index.html file with your browser to view it.

sect3.para: Before running any of the Veil2 SQL scripts, you should satisfy yourself that they will do no harm to any of your existing databases. Obviously you will not run them in your production environment. The scripts are mostly safe but they do create and drop users and roles. These are all named veil_<something> so they should not conflict with anything you are already using BUT YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED.

If you'd like to test the Veil2 installation, you should run the command:
$ make unit TESTDB=whateverdbnameyoulike
The name you give TESTDB is the name of the database that will be created for testing. This should not be the name of an existing database! If you don't provide TESTDB, the database name will be vpd.

If all is well, you'll see something like this:
... VPD database created successfully
Performing unit tests... RUNNING SETUP ...creating test users... ...creating test schema... ......creating test functions... ......creating corp context type... ......creating test corp... ......creating test corp... ......creating test corp... ......creating test corp... ...creating test parties... ......creating test roles... ......creating test context_roles... ...creating test privileges... ...setting access rights for parties... RUNNING TESTS ...views... ......checking direct_role_privileges... .........connect role and privilege... .........superuser role... .........test roles... ......checking assigned_role_info... ...authentication functions... ......checking plaintext authentication... ......checking bcrypt authentication... ...checking basic veil2 session handling... .....reset_session()... .....create_session()... .....open_connection()... .....open_connection(checking nonce handling)... ...close_connection()... ...checking dbuser-based session handling... ......checking visibility of veil2 objects... "user=marc host=/var/run/postgresql port=5432 dbname=whateverdbnameyoulike" ...context in session handling... .....create and open session(invalid context)... TESTS COMPLETE RUNNING TEARDOWN
If you see any mention of ERROR, then your installation has a problem. This will either mean that your extensions are not properly installed, or that you have found a bug. Start by carefully reading the output and see if you can figure it out for yourself. If not, see reporting bugs TODO.

When you wish to remove the databse you can do:
$ make drop TESTDB=whateverdbnameyoulike

If you are in an environment without make you have our sympathy. In this case, you can run the scripts manually. Take a look in GNUmakefile for the db and unit targets. You will see psql commands there. You can run these directly.

sect2.title: Installing The Demo
sect2.para:
We start by creating a database and installing the Veil2 database objects. We can do this using make:
$ make db TESTDB=whateverdbnameyoulike

Next, we run the demo creation script against the newly created database:
$ psql -d whateverdbnameyoulike -f demo/demo.sql
This installs the demo database, and links it to the Veil2 database objects. The demo database is now ready to use.
